docs.abstract: Some researchers find that jet lag caused by time zone changes may not be harmful to performances of athletes, but heat, humidity and smog at Beijing Olympics could affect them; photos (M)

headline.main: Jet Lag Is No Sweat, but Just Try To Beat the Heat and the Smog

docs.snippet: Air pollution. Heat and humidity. Time zone changes. All have been cited as potential issues at next month's Beijing Olympics. And the fear is that any of them can throw a superior athlete into dissolution, allowing an inferior athlete to win a compe
docs.lead_paragraph: Air pollution. Heat and humidity. Time zone changes. All have been cited as potential issues at next month's Beijing Olympics. And the fear is that any of them can throw a superior athlete into dissolution, allowing an inferior athlete to win a competition. But the truth, exercise physiologists say, is not always the same as conventional wisdom. Jet lag may have no effect on performance. Although Beijing's pollution can be a problem, the biggest drag on performance probably will come from the city's heat and humidity.

docs.abstract: China's Ministry of Culture Web site posts new rules saying foreign entertainers who have taken part in activities that China deems threat to its sovereignty will not be allowed to perform in Beijing; says background credentials for performers from Hong Kong, Macao and Taiwan wil be scrutinized; rules are attempt by China to clamp down on political dissent before Beijing Olympics (M)

headline.main: China to Bar Some Foreign Entertainers for Political Reasons

docs.snippet: Foreign entertainers who have taken part in activities that China deems a threat to its sovereignty will not be allowed to perform in the country.

byline.original: By EDWARD WONG; Huang Yuanxi contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: Foreign entertainers who have taken part in activities that China deems a threat to its sovereignty will not be allowed to perform here, according to new rules posted Thursday on the Web site of the Ministry of Culture. The rules say that the background credentials of performers from foreign countries, Hong Kong, Macao and Taiwan will be scrutinized. ''Those who used to take part in activities that harm our nation's sovereignty are firmly not allowed to perform in China,'' the rules say.

docs.abstract: Olympics are source of economic benefit to businesses large and small in China that are tapped to commemorate event; factories have been busy making all memorabilia, and some are making medals for winning athletes; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Beyond bringing honor, glory and visitors to the host city of Beijing, the Olympics are a source of economic benefit to businesses large and small that are tapped to commemorate the event. This year in China, factories have been busy making all manne
docs.lead_paragraph: Beyond bringing honor, glory and visitors to the host city of Beijing, the Olympics are a source of economic benefit to businesses large and small that are tapped to commemorate the event. This year in China, factories have been busy making all manner of pins, flags, mascots and other Olympics memorabilia. And a few lucky companies have been pressed into service to make the most valuable souvenirs of all: the medals for the winning athletes.

docs.abstract: Many at NBC are concerned about how they will be permitted to cover any unscheduled events at Summer Olympic Games in Beijing, like political protests or government crackdowns--or whether Chinese government will allow them to cover such things at all; stakes are high for network, which paid $900 million for broadcast rights, and reputation of NBC News; if it covers any controversies aggressively, it risks drawing ire of Chinese and interfering with coverage of sports events; if it shies from coverage of any protests, NBC risks being criticized in West for kowtowing to China; photos (L)
docs.snippet: A plan for 3,600 hours of coverage may collide with efforts to stifle news.
docs.lead_paragraph: For several years now NBC has meticulously planned all the details for its coverage of the many sports events at the Summer Olympics in China. But with the Games only 19 days away, many at the network are concerned about how they will be permitted to cover any unscheduled events, like political protests or government crackdowns -- or whether the Chinese government will allow them to cover such things at all.

docs.abstract: China's controversial authoritarian policies and history of dictatorship have some comparing 2008 Olympics in Beijing to 1936 Olympics in Berlin, where international event was used by Germany as propaganda vehicle; photos (M)

headline.main: Poolside View Of History At '36 Games

docs.snippet: The 93-year-old former Olympic swimmer Mary Lou Skok still marvels at the front-row seat she had for the 1936 Games in Berlin.
docs.lead_paragraph: What Mary Lou Skok would have given for a cellphone camera in 1936, when she and other United States Olympians were bused to a convention hall in Berlin to hear the chancellor of Germany, Adolf Hitler, speak. Skok, then a 21-year-old swimmer from Spokane, Wash., said, ''We couldn't understand a word, but we sat there mesmerized.''

docs.abstract: Editorial scores China for jailing critics, denying visas and threatening news organizations that negative coverage could jeopardize their chance to cover Olympic Games; says actions run counter to promise China made to International Olympic Committee; says corporate sponsors and most world leaders are also complicit, ignoring arrests; says IOC still has time and should put minimal protections in place
docs.snippet: Apart from China, no one deserves criticism more than the International Olympic Committee, which has indulged Beijing at every turn.
docs.lead_paragraph: China has gone to extraordinary lengths to spruce up its image before next month's Olympics: shuttering factories to reduce air pollution, mopping up algae in sailing waters, harassing critics and threatening journalists. To win the right to host the Games, Beijing promised to expand press freedoms for foreign reporters and implied that opening China to the world would help expand human rights more generally.

docs.abstract: Triathlete Emma Snowsill (Australia), who uses inhaler for asthma, is expected to be among favorites at 2008 Olympics (M)

headline.main: Triathlete Says Inhaler Helps Keep Her Moving

docs.snippet: Inhalers, like the one used by the triathlete Emma Snowsill, are increasingly becoming just another piece of exercise equipment for elite endurance athletes.
docs.lead_paragraph: When one of the world's top triathletes, Emma Snowsill of Australia, reaches the second transition area at the Beijing Games -- the one between the bike ride and the run -- she will find everything on the ground just as she placed it before the race. Her shoes will be side by side, tongues out so her feet can slide easily inside. Beyond them will be a hat with a short brim, upside down so it can be flipped quickly atop her head. And to the right of that will be her inhaler.

docs.abstract: Specialists insist that athletes who suffer from asthma do not gain any advantages from their medication or inhalers, and that asthma medication does nothing for someone without asthma; photo (M)

headline.main: Asthma Medications: Not a Clear Advantage

docs.snippet: Contrary to popular belief, inhaled asthma drugs do not enhance the performance of athletes who do not have asthma.
docs.lead_paragraph: In 1992, just after she had returned from winning a gold medal in the Barcelona Olympics, the swimmer Dara Torres was running with a friend on a hot, humid day in Gainesville, Fla. She was wheezing, she said, which was nothing new. She had always had breathing problems and thought nothing of it. But her friend, a hand surgeon, told Torres that she sounded like someone who had asthma. Torres's father has asthma, but it had never occurred to her that she might have it, too. She did, and as soon as she started taking asthma medication, she realized how much, and how needlessly, she had been suffering.

docs.abstract: China's Foreign Ministry says that investigators have found no evidence that fatal explosions on two public buses in Kunming were terrorist attacks linked to Beijing Olympics (M)

headline.main: Bus Blasts Not Linked To Olympics, China Says

docs.snippet: Chinese investigators have found no evidence that fatal explosions on two public buses in Kunming were terror attacks linked to the Beijing Olympics.

byline.original: By JIM YARDLEY; Zhang Jing contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: Chinese investigators have found no evidence that fatal explosions on two public buses in the southwestern city of Kunming were terrorist attacks linked to the Beijing Olympics, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said on Tuesday. On Monday, two people were killed and 14 wounded in separate blasts that struck two buses during the morning rush hour. The explosions, both caused by ammonium nitrate placed under seats, occurred within 65 minutes of each other and hit buses traveling on the same No. 54 route, state news media reported.

docs.snippet: The ferocious building boom that has transformed Beijing into a modern metropolis has also turned many of its historical neighborhoods into rubble. Nicolai Ouroussoff reports.
docs.lead_paragraph: The ferocious building boom that has transformed Beijing into a modern metropolis has also turned many of its historical neighborhoods into rubble. Nicolai Ouroussoff reports.
